page.title: 10Watton Priory
page.content: Locally known as Watton "Abbey", the ruins of the Priory are situated on the south-eastern outskirts of Watton, about 8 miles from Beverley and 5 miles from Driffield. Tanner, in "Notitia Monastica" (1787) states that a nunnery existed here in 686 AD. This follows an account by Bede of a miracle performed at the nunnery by St. John of Beverley after he became Bishop of York in 705 AD. St. John is said to have restored a nun to health. Aethelred, or Aelred, Abbot of Rievaulx, 1146-66, mentions another miracle at Watton and describes the Priory. The Saxon monastery at Watton, if ever there was one, had ceased to exist by 1066 - there is no record in the Domesday Book, although Watton had its own priest and church.
